natural problem: What is the sum of all the positive two-digit integers where one of the digits is three times the other?
natural solution: We have two cases: $\bullet$  Case 1: The tens digit is three times the unit digit. In this case we have $31,$ $62,$ and $93.$ $\bullet$  Case 2: The unit digit is three times the tens digit. In this case we have $13,$ $26,$ and $39.$
Sum up the two cases: we have $31+62+93+13+26+39 = \boxed{264}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem 
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 10 \<and> n < 100 \<and> (\<exists> a b. n = 10 * a + b \<and> (a = 3 * b \<or> b = 3 * a))"
shows  "sum id {n. n \<ge> 10 \<and> n < 100 \<and> (\<exists> a b. n = 10 * a + b \<and> (a = 3 * b \<or> b = 3 * a))} = 264"

 Sum up the two cases: we have $31+62+93+13+26+39 = \boxed{264}.$
 *)

shows  "sum id {n. n \<ge> 10 \<and> n < 100 \<and> (\<exists> a b. n = 10 * a + b \<and> (a = 3 * b \<or> b = 3 * a))} = 264"

a_0.informal problem: Find the sum of all natural numbers between 10 and 100 that can be expressed as 10a + b, where either a is three times b or b is three times a. The final answer is 264.

a_2.formal problem:

fixes sum :: int
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n m. (n>0 \<and> m>0 \<and> n<10 \<and> m<10 \<and> (n = 3*m \<or> m = 3*n)) \<longrightarrow> sum = sum + 10*n + m"
shows  "sum = 264"

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "f(n) = 10*n + 3*n"
and h1 : "f(m) = 3*10*m + m"
and h2 : "\<forall>n m. n \<in> {1..9} \<and> m \<in> {1..3}"
shows  "sum f {n. n \<in> {1..9}} + sum f {m. m \<in> {1..3}} = 264"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the sum of all the positive two-digit integers where one of the digits is three times the other? The final Answer is 264
 ### Proof

 Sum up the two cases: we have $31+62+93+13+26+39 = \boxed{264}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "f(n) = 10*n + 3*n"
and h1 : "f(m) = 3*10*m + m"
and h2 : "\<forall>n m. n \<in> {1..9} \<and> m \<in> {1..3}"
shows  "sum f {n. n \<in> {1..9}} + sum f {m. m \<in> {1..3}} = 264"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given a function $f(n) = 10n + 3n$ and $f(m) = 3*10m + m$ for $n$ in the set {1..9} and $m$ in the set {1..3}, find the sum of $f(n)$ from 1 to 9 and $f(m)$ from 1 to 3. The final answer is 264.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes sum :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "sum = (\<Sum> i \<in> {10..99}. if (\<exists> a b. a \<in> {1..9} \<and> b \<in> {0..9} \<and> i = 10*a + b \<and> (a = 3*b \<or> b = 3*a)) then i else 0)"
shows  "sum = 264"

 Sum up the two cases: we have $31+62+93+13+26+39 = \boxed{264}.$
 *)

shows  "sum = 264"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_8.formal problem:

fixes n :: nat

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x div 10 + x mod 10"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. 10 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 99 \<and> (x div 10 = 3 * (x mod 10) \<or> x mod 10 = 3 * (x div 10))"
shows  "sum f {x. 10 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 99} = 264"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the sum of all the positive two-digit integers where one of the digits is three times the other? The final Answer is 264
 ### Proof
 We have two cases: $\bullet$  Case 1: The tens digit is three times the unit digit. In this case we have $31,$ $62,$ and $93.$ $\bullet$  Case 2: The unit digit is three times the tens digit. In this case we have $13,$ $26,$ and $39.$
 Sum up the two cases: we have $31+62+93+13+26+39 = \boxed{264}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x div 10 + x mod 10"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. 10 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 99 \<and> (x div 10 = 3 * (x mod 10) \<or> x mod 10 = 3 * (x div 10))"
shows  "sum f {x. 10 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 99} = 264"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find the sum of the quotient and remainder when each two-digit integer is divided by 10, given that for each two-digit integer, either the quotient when divided by 10 is three times the remainder, or the remainder when divided by 10 is three times the quotient. The final answer is 264.
